The current review offers a comprehensive analysis of the catalytic N-benzyl hydrogenolysis debenzylation reaction, encompassing an examination of the catalytic mechanism and kinetic characteristics. Among the various catalysts employed in C−N hydrolysis, the supported palladium catalyst stands out as the most frequently employed catalyst. This review thoroughly elucidates the utilization of palladium catalyst in N-benzyl catalytic hydrogenolysis, providing insights into its activity, selectivity, and stability concerning support materials, cocatalysts, solvents, and pH conditions. These findings yield valuable insights for optimizing catalyst design and reaction conditions. Additionally, we briefly introduce the applications of other metallic catalysts such as nickel and platinum in catalyzing N-benzyl hydrogenolysis reactions. This provides valuable guidance for advancing our understanding of the hydrogenolysis reaction mechanisms, enhancing catalyst performance, and developing novel catalytic agents. These bonds find widespread utility in various fields, including organic synthesis, pharmaceuticals, and the synthesis of energetic materials. In these applications, benzyl-protected heterocyclic nitrogens are frequently employed, necessitating a subsequent deprotection process, commonly referred to as debenzylation [4–9]. The removal of benzyl groups attached to nitrogen atoms presents a more intricate challenge compared to their counterparts on oxygen atoms [10,11]. Due to the high dissociation energy of C−N bonds (e.g., 102.6 kcal mol−1 for aniline), strong coordination ability, and poor leaving ability of the −NH2 group, the cleavage of the C−N bond, especially the Csp2−N bond, remains one of the significant challenges in chemical transformations[12]. The ease of N-debenzylation is influenced by nitrogen atom substitution [13], tertiary and secondary amines can be readily debenzylated under atmospheric pressure and room temperature conditions, whereas primary amines necessitate higher pressure ( > 4 bar) and temperature ( > 40 ℃). Furthermore, the resulting hydrogenolysis products are strongly basic amines, and their toxicity can lead to the deactivation of supported noble metal catalysts [14–16], thereby requiring increased catalyst loading or the addition of acid to facilitate the reaction [17]. There are many methods for debenzylation [8,18–22]. Table 1 lists the common debenzylation methods and their characteristics. Among them, catalytic hydrogenation is one of the most popular methods for removing the benzyl group from benzylamine compounds. It is characterized by mild conditions (room temperature and atmospheric pressure), high conversion rates, and clean product formation [23], and has been widely used in the fine chemical industry [24]. In the catalytic N-benzyl hydrogenolysis for debenzylation reactions, various catalytic systems have been extensively studied [7,25–28]. Among these, the heterogeneous supported palladium catalyst is the most widely used in catalyzing the N-benzyl hydrogenolysis for debenzylation reactions [5,28–34]. However, practical applications often encounter significant challenges. These include low yields in specific debenzylation reactions [5], poor catalyst stability, and the requirement for high loading and consumption of noble metal catalysts [35–40]. Furthermore, these challenges may give rise to undesired side reactions. For instance, the presence of aromatic halogens can lead to the formation of by-products due to dehalogenation [29,30,41]. Catalytic N-benzyl hydrogenolysis in debenzylation reactions has advanced significantly within the realm of organic synthesis, establishing itself as a potent tool for the construction of complex molecules. Nevertheless, this field faces a multitude of challenges, encompassing the development of highly efficient catalysts, a deeper comprehension of underlying mechanisms, and the adaptability to a wide range of substrates. Furthermore, there is an ongoing emphasis on the challenge of designing environmentally sustainable reaction conditions while enhancing selectivity. This article's primary objective is to provide a comprehensive review of the latest advancements in catalytic N-benzyl hydrogenolysis for debenzylation reactions. It will delve into elucidating reaction mechanisms, the utilization of various catalytic systems, strategies for improving catalyst performance, and prospects for future research directions. 2 N-benzyl catalytic hydrogenolysis reactions The introduction of hydrogen molecules results in the cleavage of the X−Y σ−bond, leading to the formation of X−H and Y−H bonds, thus defining the reaction as a hydrogenolysis reaction ( Scheme 1). In the hydrogenolysis reactions of open-chain compounds, two products can be obtained, while the hydrogenolysis of cyclic compounds yields a single product [42]. This process is heavily influenced by bond polarization, with highly polarized bonds being more susceptible to cleavage than their non-polarized counterparts [42]. The N-benzyl protecting group occupies a significant position within synthetic organic chemistry [43]. Among its diverse applications, transition metal-catalyzed hydrogenolysis stands out as the most reliable method for the deprotection of benzyl and related groups [34]. Catalytic hydrogenolysis offers numerous advantages, including mild reaction conditions, high yields, and the easy removal of the by-product toluene [8,44]. This methodology proves valuable both in laboratory settings and at an industrial scale. Additionally, it benefits from the use of easily separable heterogeneous catalysts, contributing to its extensive utilization in the field of catalysis. Table 2 provides illustrative examples of various heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenolysis reactions for N-benzyl deprotection. Supported palladium catalysts are the most widely used catalysts in the N-benzyl hydrogenolysis reaction, although some researchers have explored other metals to replace or partially replace palladium, but to a lesser extent. The N-benzyl hydrogenolysis reaction is typically conducted in polar solvents such as methanol, ethanol, and acetic acid [28,33,45,46]. Additionally, some catalytic debenzylation reactions involve the addition of acidic additives because acidic conditions promote the protonation of organic amines, preventing catalyst deactivation. Hydrogenolysis catalysis uses hydrogen gas as the hydrogen source, requiring some pressure during the reaction, generally conducted at ambient temperature and pressure. Sometimes, heating conditions are also employed to expedite the reaction rate. Specific reaction conditions need to be adjusted according to different substrates, and the functional groups present in the substrates will also influence the reaction conditions to some extent. For example, if the substrate contains an O-benzyl structure, alkaline substances can be added to inhibit it [45,47]. Substrates containing aromatic halides require the addition of a buffer solution to neutralize the acid generated during the dehalogenation process, avoiding interference with the debenzylation reaction [29,30]. 2.1 Reaction mechanism Hydrogenolysis reactions involve the reduction of σ-bonds and are typically catalyzed by heterogeneous catalysts. However, the affinity of A−B−σ bonds for the catalyst surface is generally limited. Therefore, good catalytic activity of transition metals can only be observed when A or B themselves exhibit a strong tendency to bond with the metal catalyst, or when the A-B bond is in the vicinity of unsaturated functionalities. Unsaturated functional groups facilitate overlap between the σ-bonds and σ* orbitals of A−B and the d and spd orbitals of the transition metal, thus promoting catalytic activity. Moreover, the hydrogenolysis of A−B bonds is frequently initiated by the electronic effects of unsaturated moieties, referred to as "handles" ( Scheme 2). As a consequence, the strength of adsorption of the 'handle-containing' reaction product A−H will often be comparable to that of the reactant A−B, resulting in competitive adsorption of products and reactants at the catalyst's active sites. Consequently, driven by adsorption equilibrium, the surface adsorption concentration of reactants gradually diminishes throughout the reaction process, leading to a progressive reduction in the rates of most hydrogenolysis reactions ( Scheme 3) [51]. The C−N hydrogenolysis reaction, illustrated in Scheme 4, can be conceptualized as a nucleophilic displacement process. In this reaction, a proton is transferred from the surface via the nitrogen atom [51]. Several researchers emphasized the description of the process occurring during the hydrogenolysis of hexabenzylhexaazaisowurtzitane (HBIW) to generate tetraacetyldibenzylhexaazaisowurtzitane (TADBIW) in acetic anhydride ( Scheme 5, Scheme 6 1→2). Firstly, R2N−CH2−Ph adsorbs onto the catalyst surface through the benzyl group rather than the nitrogen atom, as the direct connection between the nitrogen atom and the encapsulated molecule leads to steric hindrance. Subsequently, a benzyl complex, comprising the benzyl group and Pd, is formed. This complex can react with H2 adsorbed on the catalyst, yielding toluene and R2NH. The reaction proceeds with the acetylation of the resulting product using acetic anhydride, leading to the conversion into R2NCOCH3 [52,53]. In a separate investigation, Liu et al.[54] examined the adsorption mode ( Fig. 1, A) and reaction pathway (Fig. 1, B) of HBIW on a Pd/mpg-C3N4 catalyst. According to this mechanism, one benzyl group in HBIW binds to the mpg-C3N4 catalyst surface through π-π stacking interactions, while another benzyl group interacts with Pd nanoparticles to form a π-benzyl-carbon complex. This interaction enhances the adsorption of HBIW on the catalyst, thereby improving its catalytic performance. During the reaction process, multiple benzyl groups cannot simultaneously contact active sites, leading to multiple cycles of "adsorption-reaction-desorption" until the reaction is completed. Moreover, Liu et al.[55] employed mesoporous titanium dioxide (ST) as a support to synthesize ultrafine palladium nanoparticles. They postulated that the highly dispersed ultrafine, or even sub-nanometer-sized palladium nanoparticles on the rod-shaped mesoporous ST form electron-deficient palladium (Pdn+) through strong interactions. This leads to the formation of palladium titanate (Pdn+-oxygen vacancy (Vo)-Ti3+), which makes it easier to activate hydrogen. Additionally, the dispersed Pd enhances the adsorption of HBIW. Ultimately, activated hydrogen attacks the C−N bond on HBIW ( Fig. 2) [55]. TADBIW undergoes debenzylation during hydrogenolysis to yield tetraacetylhexaazaisowurtzitane (TAIW), as illustrated in Scheme 5 (2→3). Dong et al. [40] using a Pd/DOWEX catalyst. In this process, TADBIW initially becomes protonated by H+ ions originating from the catalyst. Subsequently, activated hydrogen, facilitated by the Pd catalyst, reacts with the adsorbed protonated TADBIW, leading to the formation of protonated TAIW, which is subsequently desorbed. Guo et al. [56], suggested that hydrogen gas initially undergoes heterolysis into H+ and H at highly active sites created by the presence of small-sized Pd nanoparticles. These positively charged Pd sites enhance the adsorption capacity of substrates containing C−N bonds, which are then protonated by H. Following this, a C−N bond cleavage event occurs with a low activation energy barrier, resulting in the formation of toluene as the benzyl group combines with the remaining H. Researchers summarized a potential mechanism for catalytic N-benzyl hydrogenolysis ( Scheme 7). In this process, hydrogen gas initially adsorbs onto the catalyst surface, leading to the formation of atomic hydrogen. Subsequently, the protected C−N organic amine with the benzyl group undergoes cleavage of the coordination bond with the catalyst, resulting in the formation of toluene through the combination of the benzyl group with atomic hydrogen, while the amine forms either secondary or tertiary amines through debenzylation [8]. For the N-benzyl hydrogenolysis reaction, it is typically a heterogeneous catalytic reaction. During hydrogenolysis, the C−N bond of the substrate is cleaved, yielding the corresponding benzene and amine. This cleavage process is accomplished through active sites on the surface of the catalyst. The rate of N-benzyl hydrogenolysis reaction is influenced by the adsorption strength between the catalyst and the substrate. When the affinity between the substrate and the catalyst surface is weak, catalytic activity is limited. In this reaction process, the adsorption concentration of the substrate gradually decreases, leading to a gradual decrease in the reaction rate. The progress of the hydrogenolysis reaction is influenced by the molecular structure of the substrate. Substrates containing unsaturated functional groups typically undergo hydrogenolysis more easily because these functional groups can promote interactions between the reactants and the catalyst. These reaction processes may involve a series of adsorption, reaction, and desorption cycles until the reaction is complete. 2.2 Reaction kinetics In a study conducted by David and Vannice [29], the selectivity and reaction rate of the liquid-phase reduction of 4-chloro-N, N-dibenzylaniline (CNNDBA) to aniline using a Pd/C catalyst ( Scheme 8) were investigated. The research findings emphasized the use of the Pd/C catalyst, which resulted in both high selectivity and rapid reaction rates. Additionally, the article scrutinized the influence of various factors, such as pH value, acid-base modifiers, and reactant concentration, on the reaction rates and selectivity. To assess the potential contribution of mass transfer effects in the reaction process, the Weisz-Prater criterion was applied, with the formula for this criterion as follows: (1) N W ∙ P = R R p 2 C s D eff In this context, R represents the observed rate of reactant i per unit volume of catalyst, R p denotes the average catalyst particle radius (15 μm), C s signifies the concentration of reactant i on the catalyst surface, and D eff stands for the effective diffusion rate of reactant i in the liquid solvent within the pores. If the value of W-P is less than 0.3, it can be inferred that there is no significant mass transfer effect occurring during the reaction process. Two distinct Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanistic models were introduced to provide insights into the reaction process. Among these models, the dual active site model demonstrated enhanced data fitting capabilities. This improvement arises from its assumption of the existence of two distinct active sites, denoted as S1 and S2. Specifically, S1 is responsible for the adsorption and dissociation of H2, whereas S2 is dedicated to the adsorption of organic reactants. The proposed catalytic cycle is illustrated in Equation 2–7, where Li represents the departing group (e.g., LB representing benzyl, LC representing chlorine), and CNN’ corresponds to either N, N-diphenylaniline (NNDBA) or Chloro-N-benzylaniline (CNBA): The author derived the final rate expression for the disappearance of CNNDBA as, (8) r = r B + r C = L 1 L 2 ( k B K B + k C K C ) K CNNDBA K H 2 C CNNDBA P H 2 ( 1 + K CNNDBA C CNNDBA ) ( 1 + K H 2 1 / 2 P H 2 1 / 2 ) The author did not explicitly propose the debenzylation rate equation; however, it can be deduced through derivation as, (9) r B = L 1 L 2 k B K B K CNNDBA K H 2 C CNNDBA P H 2 ( 1 + K CNNDBA C CNNDBA ) ( 1 + K H 2 1 / 2 P H 2 1 / 2 ) In the context of the kinetic equation's structure, there are no competitive terms, and no sharing of catalytic surface adsorption sites occurs. The equation does not incorporate competitive adsorption among adsorbates but instead separately accounts for the adsorption and dissociation of H2 and the organic reactant (CNNDBA). This stands in contrast to competitive dissociative adsorption. Furthermore, based on the assumptions presented in the paper, the kinetic equation posits the existence of two distinct active sites (S1 and S2): one dedicated to H2 adsorption and dissociation, and the other specialized in the adsorption of organic reactants. This implies the presence of discrete adsorption sites on the catalyst surface, each independently facilitating the adsorption and dissociation of reactants. Therefore, considering the provided kinetic equation and the described catalytic cycle, this process can be categorized as non-competitive dissociative adsorption. Hwang et al.[28] employed the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) kinetic model to elucidate the reaction mechanism of the primary reaction ( Scheme 9, I) involving NB4FA (N-benzyl-4-fluorobenzene) to 4FA (4-fluoroaniline). Through the model and experimental data, they confirmed that the debenzylation of NB4FA proceeds via the dissociation of hydrogen and subsequent surface reaction with NB4FA. Moreover, hydrogen gas and NB4FA were found to undergo non-competitive adsorption at the catalytic sites on the Pd/C catalyst. The rate equation for the debenzylation reaction is as follows: (10) r = k K H 2 1 / 2 K NB 4 FA P H 2 1 / 2 C NB 4 FA ( 1 + K NB 4 FA C NB 4 FA ) ( 1 + K H 2 1 / 2 P H 2 1 / 2 ) In this equation, r represents the reaction rate, k is the reaction rate constant, K H 2 and K NB4FA are the surface adsorption equilibrium constants for hydrogen gas and NB4FA, respectively. P H 2 stands for hydrogen gas pressure, and C NB4FA denotes the concentration of NB4FA. The kinetic data for this reaction were experimentally determined and fitted using the L-H model, yielding the reaction rate constant and surface adsorption equilibrium constants. Tu et al.[57] investigated the debenzylation reaction of N-diphenylmethylazetidin-3-ol (DMAOL) ( Scheme 10) using Pd(OH)2/Al2O3 catalyst for hydrogenolysis. The kinetic model of this reaction suggests that the rate of diphenylmethyl removal from DMAOL is controlled by the surface reaction rate, and the adsorption of the substrate and H2 on the catalyst surface is non-competitive and dissociative. This conclusion is consistent with the findings of Hwang et al.'s research on the debenzylation reaction of NB4FA [28]. The kinetics equation for debenzylation is as follows: (11) r = k K A C A K H P ( 1 + K A C A + K B C B ) ( 1 + K H P ) 2 In the equation, k, K A, K B, and K H represent the reaction rate constants for the substrate, product, and H2, as well as the adsorption equilibrium constants. These kinetic studies indicate that in the catalytic N-benzyl hydrogenolysis for debenzylation reactions, the adsorption mode of the substrate and hydrogen gas on the catalyst surface may be non-competitive and dissociative. The substrate and hydrogen gas can independently adsorb on the catalyst surface, reacting at different sites. This mode reduces the likelihood of competitive adsorption and side reactions, thus enhancing the selectivity of the reaction. Additionally, the active intermediates generated through dissociative adsorption can also accelerate the progress of the reaction, thereby increasing the reaction rate. 3 Analysis of the catalytic performance of supported palladium catalysts in the catalytic N-benzyl hydrogenolysis debenzylation reaction Supported palladium catalysts, renowned for their high catalytic activity, broad substrate compatibility, controllability, and environmental sustainability, occupy a central position in catalyzing N-benzyl compound hydrogenolysis, making them indispensable in modern organic chemistry research and industrial production. Among these, Pd/C catalysts are the preferred choice for debenzylation reactions due to their exceptional activity and selectivity [28,29,48]. However, it's noteworthy that the catalytic activity of Pd/C catalysts tends to diminish as the interaction time between amines (both substrate and product) and palladium extends. This phenomenon arises from the pronounced coordination affinity between amines and palladium. Consequently, successful debenzylation often requires higher pressures (> 4 bar) and/or temperatures (> 40 ℃) [58–60]. Although amine salts can sometimes lead to slow catalyst poisoning [61–63], the addition of hydrochloric acid or acetic acid during the N-benzyl hydrogenolysis process can delay the rate of poisoning of the Pd/C catalyst because the formation of amine salts helps facilitate deprotection reactions [29,30,48,64,65]. Within the domain of specific N-benzyl compounds, researchers have recognized that employing Pd(OH)2/C as a catalyst can lead to more effective debenzylation reactions compared to the widely utilized Pd/C catalyst [57,66]. Moreover, some investigations suggested that combining Pd/C and Pd(OH)2/C catalysts yields superior performance compared to their individual application [50,67]. As the practical application of green synthesis continues to expand, there is a concerted effort to enhance the efficiency and environmental friendliness of the hydrogenation deprotection process. For instance, Choi et al.[68] explored the application of ionic liquids in the Pd/C-mediated debenzylation process. By employing 1-n-butyl-3-methylimidazolium (bmim) salts as co-solvents, they conducted a mild and efficient debenzylation reaction on N-benzyl and N,N-dibenzylamine derivatives. Traditional catalytic hydrogenation deprotection reactions [28,29] typically involve high-pressure batch reactors equipped with agitators, with hydrogen gas introduced into the reaction system in the form of bubbles. However, in recent years, owing to advancements in continuous flow technology and the growing emphasis on eco-friendly processes, continuous flow chemistry has witnessed a surge in its adoption within the pharmaceutical industry [57]. In a study conducted by Tu et al.[57] employed DMAOL as the starting material and utilized Pd(OH)2/Al2O3 catalyst in a micro-packed bed reactor for continuous debenzylation hydrogenolysis, yielding 3-zaetidinol. This investigation showcased that micro-packed bed reactors (μPBRs) outperformed conventional batch reactors, with the conversion rate per unit reactor volume per unit time in the micro-packed bed reactor being 100 times greater than that of the batch reactor. 3.1 Factors affecting activity Supported palladium catalysts exhibit high efficiency and remarkable activity, rendering them indispensable in catalytic reactions. Their applications span diverse fields, including organic synthesis, chemical engineering, and environmental protection. 3.1.1 Variations in activity among different supported palladium catalysts The Influence of Different Palladium Forms on Activity Among catalysts, Pd/C stands out as the most widely employed due to its remarkable activity and selectivity [29,30,43]. In most cases, the chosen catalyst is a 5–20% Pd/C catalyst, which possesses high hydrogenolysis activity and low tendency for aromatic ring reduction. Unreduced or oxidized metals and high Pd concentrations, such as the Pearlman catalyst (20% Pd(OH)2/C), are often advantageous [24]. Notably, the incorporation of both strong and weak acids as modifiers is known to significantly accelerate debenzylation reactions [29,30]. In an intriguing study by Konrad et al.[66], they discovered that the unreduced palladium catalyst (Pd(OH)2/C) displayed a notably higher rate of reduction in the debenzylation reaction compared to the reduced palladium catalyst (Pd/C). Their hypothesis revolves around the notion that PdCl2 nuclei within the activated carbon-supported particles are enveloped by Pd(OH)2. When subjected to hydrogenation conditions, the catalyst comes into contact with H2 within the reaction medium, leading to simultaneous reduction of both Pd(OH)2 and PdCl2. This reduction process results in the formation of HCl, consequently causing a reduction in pH: (12) [ Pd ( OH ) 2 / C + PdCl 2 ] + 2 H 2 → Pd / Cl + 2 H 2 O + 2 HCl Furthermore, in kinetic studies, Tu et al. found that the activation energy for the hydrogenolysis debenzylation reaction investigated using a Pd(OH)2/Al2O3 catalyst was significantly lower, with an activation energy of 18.6 kJ/mol, compared to the value of 138.4 kJ/mol reported by Hwang for the same reaction catalyzed by Pd/C [28,57]. These findings suggest that palladium hydroxide catalysts exhibit superior performance compared to palladium catalysts. Zhang et al.[39] enhanced the dispersion of Pd on MC using a precipitation method. This particular preparation approach led to the formation of various Pd species on the carbon support's surface, including Pd0, PdO, and Pd(OH)2. The presence of hydrogen in the reaction system facilitated the in-situ reduction of PdOx to Pd0, contributing to the catalytic activity of HBIW hydrogenation. This enhanced activity may be attributed to the formation of highly active palladium catalysts on palladium(II) hydroxide during the deposition-precipitation process. Additionally, it suggests the potential formation of chemical bonds like Pd-O-Pd at the interface of palladium particles and Pd(OH)2 during debenzylation [67]. Overall, palladium catalysts prepared through the deposition-precipitation method often exhibit enhanced activity, potentially due to strong interactions between palladium particles and and Pd(OH)2 [69]. Studer and Blaser[30], utilizing CNNDBA as a model compound, determined that the choice of catalyst had minimal influence on the relative or absolute rates of debenzylation. This observation contrasts with other debenzylation reactions, underscoring the extent to which catalyst effectiveness depends on substrate and reaction conditions. Additionally, it was noted that carbon-supported Pd was more efficient for debenzylation when compared to PdO or Pd(OH)2 [30]. Li et al.[50] conducted experiments with a 1:1 mixture of Pd/C and Pd(OH)2/C catalysts, which exhibited higher yields compared to using each catalyst individually. This catalytic system demonstrated excellent performance for debenzylation of benzyl-protected aliphatic and aromatic amines, significantly reducing reaction times (about half the time reduced) and displaying catalytic activity in reactions that a single catalyst could not promote. Furthermore, in the catalytic hydrogenolysis debenzylation reaction of N-benzyl-piperidine intermediates, the composite catalyst of Pd/C and Pd(OH)2/C was found to be more effective than individual catalysts [67]. But currently, there is still a lack of explanation for this phenomenon. Effect of Support on the Activity of Supported Palladium Catalysts David and Vannice[29] conducted research and found that the influence of catalyst supports on selectivity was relatively insignificant. The turnover frequency (TOF) on Pd/C catalysts is 2–40 times higher than that of Pd dispersed on Al2O3, TiO2, and SiO2. In their kinetic studies, it was found that the low rates of catalysts supported on oxides were not due to mass transfer limitations, as their Weisz-Prater (W-P) numbers were much smaller than those of Pd/C catalysts. It is more likely due to insufficient in situ high-temperature reduction of passivated catalysts before use. In the hydrogenolysis-based debenzylation process of TADBIW, Pd/DOWEX (yield 98%) demonstrated superior catalytic performance when contrasted with Pd/C (yield 92%) and Pd/silica gel (no product). This catalyst system allowed for milder reaction conditions, enabling a reduction in palladium loading from 1% to 0.4%, alongside a simultaneous increase in yield from 92% to 98%. This enhancement can be attributed to a synergistic effect between palladium and the acidic resin [40]. The partitioning of a heterogeneous catalyst between two immiscible phases (e.g. water/toluene) should depend on the hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity of the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the manipulation of surface polarity can determine the phase in which the catalyst will be retained [70]. Gruber et al.[70] used n-octyldimethylsilyl chloride to surface modify the oxide and prepare a supported palladium catalyst. This catalyst was used in the N-debenzylation reaction of N-benzylaminoethanol ( Scheme 11), and it was found that the hydrophobic catalyst showed a higher conversion rate than the hydrophilic catalyst. This may be because it may be due to the higher solubility of H2 in the solvent toluene. Although surface polarity may affect the distribution of catalysts in different phases, in practical applications, the selection of catalysts is influenced by numerous factors including reaction conditions, catalyst structure, etc., necessitating a more comprehensive and systematic study. Su et al. [71] proposed a strategy for preparing Pd/C catalysts on carbon hollow spheres using a microwave discharge method, achieving high activity and stability in catalytic hydrogenolysis for N-benzyl group removal. By utilizing carbon-induced arc and high temperature under microwave radiation, rapid reduction of metal precursors was achieved, limiting the growth of nanoparticles during the reduction process and resulting in catalysts with small particle size (Average particle size is 3–4 nm) and high dispersion. Pd/MicroCHS and Pd/MesoCHS catalysts exhibited superior activity in the debenzylation reaction compared to commercial Pd/C, demonstrating their excellent performance. This provides a new perspective and method for the design and preparation of carbon-based metal catalysts with high catalytic activity and stability. The Impact of Palladium Particle Size on Catalyst Activity The cleavage of the C-N bond is a size-sensitive reaction. For 1.8 nm palladium catalysts, the highest concentrations of Pd2+ and Pd4+ cations are 29% and 33%, respectively, while for 15.5 nm palladium catalysts, the highest concentration of metallic Pd0 is 69% [56]. Moreover, it has been proposed that as the size of Pd nanoparticles increases, the relative content of oxidized Pd species significantly decreases [56]. Other researchers have also observed a dependence between the oxidation state and Pd size, The high-valence Pd species in the catalyst may originate from the oxidation of unstable Pd near the surface of small particles [72,73]. Guo et al.[56] proposed that substrates containing C-N bonds, such as TADBIW and HBIW, commonly used in the industrial synthesis of CL-20, feature electron-rich moieties. In this particular reaction, higher valence states display superior reactivity compared to metallic Pd(0). The conclusion was drawn through calculations that the high-coordinated Pd atoms lying on terrace sites in the hydrogenation reaction. Pd 3d XPS confirmed that the high-coordinated Pd atoms lying on terrace sites were prone to oxidation, thus exhibiting a positive charge state on small Pd NPs. Experimental validation showed an increase in the adsorption capacity of the substrate TADBIW with decreasing Pd NPs size. The adsorption capacities of TADBIW on the 1.8 nm, 4.2 nm, and 15.5 nm catalysts were 14.7 mg/g, 10.5 mg/g, and 8.3 mg/g, respectively. Pd nanoparticles can generate more positive charge sites, which then facilitate the activation of hydrogen with the substrate through nucleophilic processes. Additionally, they promote the cleavage of the C-N bond with lower activation energy, thereby enhancing the catalytic stability of substrates containing C-N bonds. The catalyst PdSC8–100Air, which had the most positive Pd sites, exhibited the highest yield (96%), while the catalyst PdSC0–100, which had the largest Pd NPs, showed the lowest yield (61%) [56]. Maksimowski et al.[74] synthesized a 10 wt% Pd catalyst and investigated its deactivation in the hydrogenolysis debenzylation reaction of HBIW. Their study revealed that the aggregation of palladium particles led to a decline in the catalytic performance of HBIW debenzylation. This aggregation issue is a well-known consequence of the relatively weak interactions between carbon supports and active metals, which results in Pd aggregation. To address the reduction in active sites, an increase in Pd loading is typically considered. However, it's essential to note that surface atoms on palladium particles play a pivotal role in the debenzylation reaction, and merely augmenting palladium loading doesn't effectively facilitate the conversion process [54]. Hence, it becomes imperative to enhance the interaction between the support and Pd to maintain the favorable dispersion of Pd. In a related study, Zhang et al.[39] delved into the impact of different carbon supports on the hydrogenolysis debenzylation of palladium-based catalysts. They uncovered that the disordered mesoporous structure of carbon resulted in a high surface concentration of ultrafine Pd particles, thus promoting the hydrogenation debenzylation reaction of HBIW. The precipitation method enhanced the dispersion of Pd on carbon MC, where the palladium particles on carbon MC were composed of large particles with a diameter of 6.8 nm, consisting of small particles with a diameter of 2.1 nm. Its yield reached 80%, even 2% higher than that of the commercial E101 NE/W catalyst. Additionally, the Pd/MC catalyst exhibited excellent durability, with the yield remaining at 70% after three cycles of reuse, while the commercial E101 NE/W catalyst experienced a sharp drop in yield (<15%) after the second cycle of reuse. Fernandez-Puertas et al.[75] investigated the catalytic debenzylation performance in a trickle bed reactor using four reduced prototype SARATECH palladium polymer-based spherical activated carbon (PBSAC) catalysts designed for pharmaceutical applications, which were supplied by Blücher GmbH (SEM image in Fig. 3). Their emphasis was particularly on the unique characteristics of the 200–5PdC catalyst, which consisted of spherical entities with uniform sizes and surface structures, indicating an even distribution of palladium on the surface. In contrast, the 200–10PdC catalyst also exhibited a spherical shape, but its surface was rougher, leading to the formation of fine palladium particles. The two 100μm Pd/C catalysts comprised elliptical and spherical particles of varying sizes. Notably, the authors observed a correlation between palladium loading and particle size, with smaller particles capable of accommodating more metal. In their study, they employed three benzyl-substituted substrates, namely N-benzyl-4-methoxyaniline, methyl 4-(benzylamino)benzoate, and N-benzylaniline, for the debenzylation reactions ( Scheme 12). Using the 100–5PdC catalyst, they achieved an approximate 50% conversion rate for aniline 2, while complete conversion was realized when employing the 200–5PdC and 200–10PdC catalysts. However, for the 100–10PdC catalyst, the HPLC results only displayed the toluene peak, suggesting that product aniline 2 was adsorbed onto the catalyst's surface, which could potentially contribute to catalyst deactivation. Metal Interacts with Support Metal oxides are employed as effective strategies for enhancing the stability of active metals and maintaining high catalytic activity due to the strong interaction between metals and carriers [55]. In a study conducted by Lou et al.[5], they observed that commercial titanium dioxide P25, used as a carrier for PdFe bimetallic catalysts, demonstrated remarkable performance in the HBIW conversion reaction, yielding up to 76%. It has been reported that the dispersion of Pd on TiO2 contributes to the formation of a strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [76,77]. This SMSI induces electron transfer between Pd and TiO2, which could be another factor contributing to enhanced catalytic performance [76]. However, in this study, titanium dioxide exhibited a non-porous structure, and catalytic activity could only be maintained at high Pd loading (6.5% wt.), limiting the atomic utilization of palladium. To address this limitation and enhance the atomic utilization of palladium while reducing its loading, Liu et al.[55] conducted research utilizing mesoporous titanium dioxide (ST) as a carrier to synthesize ultrafine palladium nanoparticles. The results demonstrated that Pd could infiltrate the pores and lattice of ST, forming ultrafine or even sub-nanometer-sized particles (average diameter of 1.2 nm) with high dispersion. These particles exhibited exceptional activity in the hydrogenation of HBIW. Studies have shown that Pd can occupy the pores of the carrier, leading to the distortion of the titanium lattice structure [78]. Furthermore, nanocrystalline anatase and rutile, with their high surface energies, are susceptible to phase transformations and grain boundary sliding, creating nanoscale voids [79,80]. pH and the presence of metal salt precursors have been found to facilitate interactions between salts and the carrier [81]. And at a certain content, Pd can be doped into the titanium dioxide lattice [78]. Researchers have therefore hypothesized that a strong interaction forms between metal Pd and the unstable edges and channel surfaces of titanium. This interaction leads to penetration of Pd into the pores or even the lattice, particularly under the influence of pH and interactions with high-salt carriers [55]. The enhanced dispersity of Pd may be attributed to the close match between the lattice of Pd and the rutile phase, reinforcing the interaction between Pd and TiO2. This reinforcement prevents the agglomeration of Pd particles during the calcination process [82]. The Impact of Promoter on Catalytic Activity Substituting non-precious metals for palladium in part can lead to the formation of bimetallic catalysts, effectively enhancing palladium utilization and demonstrating superior catalytic performance compared to pure palladium, as reported in numerous studies [83–90]. Hasegawa et al.[91] made an intriguing discovery when they prepared catalysts by combining specific noble metal elements with compounds containing divalent palladium, such as 5% Pd-0.5% Rh/C, 5% Pd-0.5% Au/C, and 4.95% Pd-1% Pt/C; these catalysts exhibited remarkable activity even at low temperatures. During the N-phenyl-benzylamine hydrogenolysis process, these catalysts displayed hydrogen adsorption capacities 3.1–3.3 times higher than conventional 5% Pd/C catalysts. In 2008, Pavlovich et al.[92] introduced a Pd-Ir/C catalyst, with a minimum Pd content of 6 wt%, which demonstrated a remarkable 76% yield in the HBIW dephenylation reaction, as disclosed in their patent. More recently, PdFe bimetallic catalysts have also been employed in the HBIW dephenylation reaction, with iron playing a crucial role in promoting Pd deposition on the carrier surface [5]. Subsequent investigations revealed that the addition of trace amounts of iron led to a synergistic catalytic effect between Pd and Fe, resulting in enhanced H2 activation efficiency [93]. This synergy formed a PdFe alloy, facilitating the high dispersion of Pd and more efficient hydrogen activation. Moreover, hydrogen species from the Pd surface diffused onto the Fe surface, establishing a state of high coverage. As the Pd surface consumed activated hydrogen, hydrogen species could migrate back from the Fe surface [93]. Niobium pentoxide (Nb2O5) has garnered significant attention in the realm of acidic solid catalysts due to its possession of both Brønsted acid and Lewis acid characteristics. It finds applications in esterification, amide formation, imine synthesis, and dehydration reactions. In a study by Yamamoto et al.[34], it was revealed that while Nb2O5/C does not exhibit hydrogenolysis catalytic activity, it effectively facilitates the deprotection of N-benzyl protecting groups when used in conjunction with Pd/C. Under co-hydrogenolysis conditions involving Pd/C and Nb2O5/C, the deprotection of both N-Cbz and O-Bn-protected groups proceeds smoothly and with significantly reduced reaction times ( Scheme 13). Furthermore, a mixture of 10% Pd/C and 10% Nb2O5/C can be reused for at least three cycles without any noteworthy loss in catalytic activity. Although a slight decrease in catalytic activity is observed during the fourth and fifth runs, there is still an evident acceleration effect when compared to reactions using standalone Pd/C catalysts. Crucially, the deprotection process exhibits minimal leaching of Pd (<0.1 ppm) and Nb (<1.0 ppm), as confirmed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). 3.1.2 Impact of Solvents on the Activity of Supported Palladium Catalysts In hydrogenolysis processes, solvents often play a pivotal role [30,94], impacting various aspects, including the solubility of H2, the adsorption mechanisms of solvent molecules at catalytic active sites, the aggregation of catalyst particles, and non-covalent interactions between reactant or non-bonded interactions between product molecules and solvent. The judicious choice of a suitable solvent can effectively expedite the hydrogenolysis of benzyl groups [95]. Hwang et al.[28] conducted an investigation wherein they observed that polar solvents like methanol (MeOH, 8.62 s−1), tetrahydrofuran (THF, 2.93 s−1), and 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-Me-THF, 4.24 s−1) exhibited substantially higher TOF values than the non-polar solvent, toluene (0.51 s−1), during the deprotection of NB4FA. This finding aligns with the hydrogenolysis phenomenon of CNNDBA previously reported by Studer and Blaser [30]. Additionally, Hwang et al.[28] found that among polar solvents, methanol displayed superior hydrogenation activity compared to THF and 2-Me-THF in the deprotection of NB4FA. This may be related to the solubility of the debenzylation product in different polar solvents. The best solvents for the debenzylation reaction of CNNDBA are polar aprotic solvents such as tetrahydrofuran (THF) and acetone. This is because the solubility of the debenzylation product CNDBA largely depends on the nature of the solvent, and polar protic solvents such as methanol and acetic acid only provide limited solubility. Rich in transferable protons can enhance the initial reaction rate and turnover frequencies (TOFs) [29]. Although the authors pointed out the influence of solubility, other factors such as the interaction between the solvent and reactants/products may also affect the solvent's choice. Therefore, further research and data support may be needed for the interpretation of these findings. Furthermore, in the context of the N-debenzylation reaction of N-benzylaminoethanol, it was observed that a mixture of water and toluene exhibited heightened activity and selectivity compared to the use of individual solvents. The optimal volume ratio was determined to be 75:25. This enhancement can be attributed to the favorable combination of reactants (N-benzylaminoethanol and H2) in the organic phase, coupled with the product's high solubility in water [70]. Azaadamantane serves as the structural scaffold for cage-type nitroamine energetic compounds. Luo et al.[6] employed a hydrogenolysis method using Pd(OH)2/C catalyst to remove the benzyl group from azaadamantane, yielding the precursor of nitro-substituted azaadamantane ( Scheme 14). Due to the chemical reactivity of the N-H bond, the debenzylation product exhibits instability under acidic conditions. This method, using acetic anhydride as a solvent and under Pd(OH)2/C conditions, involves debenzylation followed by acetylation, resulting in the formation of 2,4,9-tribenzyl-2,4,9-triazaadamantane-7-ol. Within the reaction, acetic anhydride assumes a dual role as both an acylating agent, participating in the formation of amides with the amines, and as an acidic catalyst, facilitating the progression of the reaction. In the HBIW debenzylation reaction, acetic anhydride serves a dual purpose as both a solvent and an acetylating agent, reacting with the amino group to protect the intermediate from ring opening [54]. Dimethylformamide (DMF), as a cosolvent, also plays an important role in the reaction. It acts as a Lewis base and can neutralize acids generated in the medium, maintaining the medium around neutrality. This increases the solubility of HBIW in the hydrogenolysis medium, accelerates the hydrogenolysis acetylation reaction rate, reduces the time HBIW spends in the hydrogenolysis medium, and prevents damage to the cage structure [96]. It's noteworthy that by substituting DMF with solvents like dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), CH3OH, 1,4-dioxane, THF, or dimethylglycol, the reaction does not occur [54]. 3.1.3 The impact of additives on the activity of supported palladium catalysts Kieboom and Freifelder [51,97] proposed that debenzylation involves the attack on the benzyl carbon by a Pd-coordinated 'hydride-ion'. The protonation of adjacent heteroatoms facilitates this attack. However, Studer and Blaser[30] discovered that while the addition of acid significantly accelerates debenzylation, high concentrations of acid can decrease the overall rate of debenzylation and seem to selectively poison the catalyst. This poisoning phenomenon occurs only when the substrate is fully protonated, and there is an adequate amount of 'free' HCl present. They suggested that this may be due to the presence of two different types of catalytic centers on Pd participating in the debenzylation of CNNDBA. One center catalyzes the removal of the first and second benzyl groups and is sensitive to excess acid, while the other primarily catalyzes the removal of the first benzyl group and is less sensitive to acid. In contrast, Nielsen[98] found that for the HBIW debenzylation reaction, H2SO4, HCl, or HBr are preferred inorganic acid catalysts, but HI is not and can be added directly to the reaction mixture before hydrogenolysis. Using HBr yields optimal results, especially when generated through dehydrohalogenation of selected organic bromides (such as benzyl bromide or bromobenzene). The generation of HBr and acetyl bromide is relatively slow, which facilitates the hydrogenation reaction more effectively. The interaction between bromides and palladium in the medium enhances the absorption of HBIW and the desorption of intermediates on the palladium surface [99]. Bromides act as co-catalysts to facilitate the desorption of debenzylation products from the surface of palladium nanoparticles, but an excess of bromides is detrimental to the progress of the debenzylation reaction [100]. It is well known that in the hydrogenolysis of chlorinated organic compounds catalyzed by Pd/C, the C-Cl bonds can be cleaved, releasing HCl [101–103], where bases (inorganic bases or tertiary amines) are typically used as HCl acceptors and reaction promoters [104–107]. When tertiary benzylamine acts as an HCl acceptor in the hydrogenolysis of chlorides, catalytic hydrogenation should be performed to directly generate the corresponding amine hydrochloride salts. By employing this strategy, Cheng et al.[48] effectively addressed the issues of instability and water solubility associated with small amine molecules in traditional hydrogenolysis systems by introducing 1,1,2-trichloroethane. In this method, the C-Cl bond undergoes hydrogenolysis under Pd/C catalysis, leading to the generation of HCl and chlorinated alkanes. Organic amines, which act as receptors for HCl, play a dual role by accelerating the hydrogenation reaction and significantly influencing the hydrogenation rate through modulation of the amount of polychlorinated alkanes. This innovative approach combines debenzylation and salification into a single step, providing a practical solution for applications in asymmetric synthesis and natural product synthesis ( Scheme 15). In the quest to obtain N-unprotected tetrahydroquinolines, Bohórquez et al.[108] employed a solvent mixture of ethanol and dichloromethane ( Scheme 16，1) to improve substrate dissolution. After a reaction time of 4–6 hours, followed by separation and purification processes, yields ranging from 64% to 96% were achieved. However, when using alkyl-substituted secondary benzylamines as substrates, no N-debenzylation reaction occurs. Modifiers, such as acids or bases, have a dual role in chemical reactions. They not only interact with organic reagents but also engage with the surface of the catalyst. For example, activated carbon can bind to surface groups that contain heteroatoms, and these groups can exhibit a range of acidic, neutral, or basic properties. This binding imparts amphiphilic characteristics to the carbon support [109]. Furthermore, the surface properties of the catalyst can vary depending on the pH of the solution. In alkaline conditions, sites with deprotonated carboxyl groups tend to attract cations, while in acidic conditions, oxygen-containing surface groups attract anions. In the reduction process of CNNDBA under acidic conditions, the positively charged amine diffuses to the Pd active sites, while no significant interaction is observed between carbon sites with different charges. This suggests that the presence of modifiers and the pH of the solution play crucial roles in the behavior of catalyst surfaces and the overall reaction mechanisms [29]. Research has shown that the removal of benzyl groups from nitrogen atoms connected to pyridine rings is challenging. Ji et al.[33] attempted various reaction conditions for the debenzylation of N-tertbutyloxycarbonyl (N-Boc) and N-benzyl (N-Bn) double-protected 2-aminopyridine. Both hydrogenolysis debenzylation systems using Pd/C as the catalyst and oxidative debenzylation systems with 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyanobenzoquinone (DDQ) as the oxidant failed to remove the N-benzyl group. Even the use of ceric ammonium nitrate (CAN) for oxidative debenzylation resulted in only a 26% yield. In response to these challenges, they switched to a catalyst with a mass fraction of 20% Pd(OH)2/C, raised the temperature to 60°C, and introduced acetic acid. Through a series of improvements, the debenzylation yield increased from the initial 26–60% ( Scheme 17). Because σ bonds with a higher degree of polarization are more susceptible to hydrogenolysis than non-polar bonds. The addition of acetic acid promotes the protonation of the pyridine ring, which can polarize the N-Bn bond, making it more electrophilic and facilitating the attack of surface hydrides during the hydrogenolysis process. In principle, benzyl serves as an effective protecting group for sulfonamide compounds, and its deprotection can be achieved through hydrogenation reactions, a process orthogonal to the removal of many other protecting groups. Unfortunately, the hydrogenation of the benzyl moiety, especially in N-benzyl sulfonamides, presents several challenges [110,111]. For N-benzyl sulfonamides, the aromatic nature of the benzyl group and the presence of the sulfonamide moiety may render the hydrogenation reaction less facile. Johnson et al.[112] observed that N-acyl-N-benzyl sulfonamides can undergo hydrogenolysis under mild conditions. Based on these observations, they developed a reversible and safe capture method by adding di-tert-butyl dicarbonate to activate N-benzyl sulfonamides for hydrogenolysis ( Table 3). Specifically, the Boc group renders the sulfonamide's benzyl group highly reactive to hydrogenolysis, and this activation can be reversed by acid treatment, yielding the free sulfonamide. This method offers high yields and eliminates the need for intermediate product separation. The subsequent removal of the Boc group restores the sulfonamide's original structure. 3.2 Factors affecting selectivity Pd/C catalysts are known for their versatility in hydrogenating a range of functional groups, encompassing CC, CC, C N, R−NO, and aryl halides. Therefore, if these functional groups coexist within the same molecule, selective debenzylation is not easy to achieve, and interference with them should be avoided as much as possible. Particularly, when a molecule houses both amine compounds and low oxidation state sulfur groups, the hydrogenolysis reaction frequently proceeds sluggishly, necessitating substantial catalyst quantities [30]. Achieving selective removal of a single benzyl group from a multi-benzyl-containing molecule proves to be a formidable challenge. One potential approach to address this complexity involves conducting hydrogenation under varying conditions, as the order of hydrogenolysis between N-benzyl and O-benzyl groups hinges on factors such as pH and solvent choice. Despite some efforts, achieving the desired selectivity remains a formidable task in most cases, yielding unsatisfactory outcomes. Consequently, the development of innovative methods for achieving selective debenzylation remains a significant challenge in the field [113]. 3.2.1 Differences in selectivity of different supported palladium catalysts The Influence of Different Forms of Palladium on Selectivity Olofson [114] has developed several chloroacetic alkylating reagents for efficiently removing N-alkyl groups from tertiary amines. Another alternative method to chloroformate reagents is hydrogenolysis over a Pd/C catalyst, either by hydrogenolysis [115] or under catalytic transfer hydrogenation [116–118] conditions, to remove benzyl groups from secondary and tertiary benzylamines. However, these conditions often remove the benzyl group more rapidly from benzyl ethers than from benzylamines. In the case of certain N-benzyl compounds, the use of the Pearlman catalyst (Pd(OH)2/C) has proven more successful for debenzylation reactions than the commonly used Pd/C catalyst [57,66]. The Pearlman catalyst has also been employed for the cleavage of benzyl ethers [119], indicating that selective N-debenzylation is challenging. For N-benzyl, unlike the O-benzyl bond, which is prone to cleavage [10,11,47,101,120,121], steric hindrance affects the adjacent benzyl group [47,120]. This implies that during the cleavage process of N-benzyl, the O-benzyl bond typically also breaks [122]. However, the hydrogenolysis of benzyl ethers can be promoted by acids and inhibited by bases. Substrates containing amines can effectively remove trace amounts of acid, thereby slowing down or even preventing O-benzyl removal [45]. Bernotas et al.[45] reported the selective N-debenzylation of amines even in the presence of hydroxyl and adjacent benzyl ethers using the Pearlman catalyst. This debenzylation reaction fully and selectively removes only the N-benzyl group from secondary and tertiary amines. Even with prolonged reaction times, there was no significant cleavage observed in the benzyl ethers present in the substrates. The authors speculate that the amines can neutralize all the free acidic species in the reaction, while Pd(OH)2/C itself does not possess acidity like Pd/C. In another study, Yoshida et al.[32] utilized Pd(OH)2/C as a catalyst for the rapid debenzylation of N-benzylamines at room temperature, yielding debenzylation products. Interestingly, this process did not affect acid-sensitive groups present in the substrates, such as triethysilyl, rert-butyidimcthylsilyl, tetrahydropyranyl, and acetonide. The reaction was conducted in a highly polar methanol solvent, hydrogenated under a hydrogen pressure of 101 kPa, and completed within a few hours, yielding high product yields (ranging from 81–99%). This is an intriguing observation in the selective debenzylation reaction using Pearlman's catalyst, as it achieves selective removal of the N-benzyl group while preserving other acid-sensitive functional groups under the conditions employed. The Impact of Supports on Selectivity Supported palladium catalysts supported on different materials, such as C, SiO2, and Al2O3, showed varying performances in debenzylation reactions. Among these, the Pd/C catalyst demonstrated the highest conversion rate and remarkable debenzylation selectivity (>99%) in the NB4FA debenzylation reaction, whereas the conversion rates were relatively lower for Pd/SiO2 and Pd/Al2O3 catalysts [28]. In the case of non-enantioselective hydrogenation of N-benzyl ethylamine, Pd/BaCO3 exhibited superior stereoselectivity, as reported in studies [31,123]. Pandarus and colleagues[124] utilized various types of support materials as carriers, including C, Al2O3, poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PVPy), and Smopex-111. These support materials were used in Metal Vapour Synthesis technology to prepare supported palladium nanoparticle catalysts. By uniformly dispersing palladium nanoparticles on these carriers, researchers achieved selective deprotection reactions of benzyl-protected phenols and anilines. The choice of carrier plays a crucial role in catalytic activity and selectivity, with carbon support exhibiting the best performance, while Smopex-111 demonstrated complete inertness. These results indicate that the dispersion state and characteristics of supported palladium nanoparticles on different carriers have a significant impact on catalytic activity. They successfully promoted the hydrogenation reaction of benzyl-protected phenols and anilines, achieving selective removal of N-benzyl groups. This may be attributed to their ability to effectively stabilize palladium nanoparticles in the reaction, reducing palladium leaching, and thereby enhancing the efficiency of selective removal of N-benzyl groups. The success of this method demonstrates the potential application prospects of supported palladium nanoparticles in organic synthesis, enabling efficient conversion and selective removal of benzyl compounds. 3.2.2 Influence of solvents on the selectivity of supported palladium catalysts In organic synthesis, solvents play a crucial role in determining reaction rates and product distribution. Polar solvents appear to promote debenzylation [30]. Hwang et al.[28] have explored the selective debenzylation of chlorinated aromatic. When compared to non-polar solvents (toluene), polar solvents like methanol, THF, and 2-Me-THF have demonstrated higher conversion rates and greater selectivity toward the desired product (4FA) in NB4FA reactions. It was found that the reaction pathway is influenced by the type of solvent. In polar solvents, the primary pathway involves rapid debenzylation to generate 4FA, followed by defluorination to produce aniline; whereas in non-polar solvents, the defluorination of NB4FA was observed even at low conversion rates (<10%) [28]. The solvent properties significantly affect the solubility of the substrate, and Studer and Blaser [30] suggested that for the hydrogenation reaction of CNNDBA on Pd catalysts, the selectivity of dehalogenation increases with the increase in the solvent's dielectric constant, as polar protic solvents are particularly favorable for dechlorination reactions [29]. The study revealed that unless alcoholic solvents were used, catalytic hydrogenolysis typically did not lead to N-debenzylation, but rather resulted in N-alkylation as a side reaction [9]. To address this challenge, Bailey et al.[9] successfully employed trifluoroethanol as a solvent, achieving highly reliable hydrogenolysis across a wide range of substrates ( Scheme 18). The mono-debenzylation of N, N-dibenzyl-2-(1 H-indol-3-yl)ethan-1-amine does not occur in methanol and ethanol, but in trifluoroethanol, complete deprotection product appeared after 3 hours (about 5%), increased to approximately 1% after 24 hours, and reached 20%. Trifluoroethanol not only provides faster and more reliable deprotection but also avoids potential N-alkylation. Moreover, their optimized conditions enabled efficient N-debenzylation, even in the presence of O-benzyl groups. Fu et al.[46] conducted Pd/C-catalyzed hydrogenolysis reactions of N-benzyl protecting groups in selective debenzylation experiments using tetrahydrofuran solvent. With the assistance of electron-donating methoxy groups on the benzene ring of the benzyl group, the product yield for debenzylation of dibenzylimine compound derivatives with benzyl ether protecting groups reached 79% in THF solvent. During the preparation of enantiopure 3,4-bis-tert-butoxypyrroline N-oxides, a slow debenzylation reaction was observed when using methanol, Pd/C, or Pd(OH)2/C, and H2 (1 atm). Additionally, it was observed that the tert-butyl ether of the intermediate product underwent partial hydrogenolysis, leading to a significant formation of 4-tert-butoxypyrrolidin-3-ol. However, in the presence of acetic acid (10 equivalents), the hydrogenolysis of the ether was effectively suppressed, resulting in an 87% yield ( Scheme 19) [125]. To minimize unwanted side reactions, Kovács et al.[17] employed a 10% Pd/C catalyst and a mixture of dichloromethane and methanol for the hydrogenolysis of compound 1 ( Scheme 20). Increasing the methanol volume fraction to 30% led to an improved hydrogenolysis rate, resulting in a separation yield of 79% for compound 2 (Scheme 20). Methanol, similar to other protonic and polar solvents, proved highly effective in the hydrogenolysis of the oxetane ring and removing the benzyl-protecting group, thus enhancing the reaction rate. Dichloromethane acted as a preventive measure against side reactions. In the N-debenzylation of N-benzylaminoethanol, Gruber et al.[70] employed a solvent mixture of water and toluene (in a 75:25 vol ratio). The Pd/C catalyst was amenable to reuse via filtration or phase separation. Even after the third run, both conversion rate and selectivity increased. This increase, particularly in selectivity, was attributed to the accumulation of byproducts that were only sparingly soluble in water, altering the catalyst's selectivity behavior. The product, aminoethano (AE), was soluble only in water, while the hydrophobic catalyst was mainly dispersed in toluene. Most of the major byproduct, benzyl alcohol, resided in the organic layer, which facilitated product purification. Removing the protection from N-benzyl amides poses a considerably challenging task [22,112,126,127], as the conditions typically employed for removal may be incompatible with other functional groups present in the molecule. This severely limits the applicability of benzyl as a protecting group for the amide functionality, which is readily available and inexpensive [22]. One approach to enhance the rate of benzylamine hydrogenation is by introducing acid into the reaction mixture, generating benzylamine salts that are more readily cleaved than benzylamine itself [128]. However, the addition of acid promotes amide hydrolysis. Some researchers have utilized Pd/C catalysts under mild temperatures and moderate pressures (40°C and 50 psi H2) to facilitate benzyl removal reactions, while employing neutral solvents (THF or THF/alcohol mixtures) to prevent amide hydrolysis [129]. 3.2.3 The influence of pH on selectivity Erhardt[130] reported high selectivity for mono-debenzylation products when using alkyl-N-(benzyl)2·HCl as the substrate. Studer and Blaser[30] confirmed that acidic conditions favored debenzylation reactions, while alkaline conditions were more conducive to dehalogenation reactions. In the synthesis of [(N, N′-dibenzylamino)ethyl]-o-carboranes, it was observed that under conventional conditions (Pd/C and H2), complete cleavage was not achieved [131]. It has been reported that using catalytic amounts of HCl as a modifier, mono- or dibenzyl derivatives can undergo debenzylation rapidly and selectively [30]. Inspired by this, Lee et al.[131], under catalytic hydrogenation conditions (H2, Pd/C catalyst), with HCl as a modifier, selectively removed the N-benzyl group from o-carboranylamines, yielding the corresponding secondary amine with a yield of >80%. A highly selective N-benzyl cleavage was achieved under mild and acidic reaction conditions, and this method was compatible with other o-carboranyl alkyl groups such as methyl and phenyl groups. To investigate whether the effect of acidic or basic additives on dibenzyl removal is similar to debenzylation, Tu et al. [57] conducted experiments by adding acetic acid and triethylamine to the solution. The results showed that acidic conditions favored the removal of dibenzyl groups, while alkaline conditions inhibited dibenzyl removal, similar to debenzylation. Studer and Blaser's model did not consider the acid generated during the dehalogenation process. To counteract the influence of pH changes on the overall reaction rate due to the formation of HCl during dechlorination reaction. David and Vannice[29] investigated the kinetics of hydrogenolysis of CNNDBA on supported palladium catalysts in buffered solvents. They emphasized the significant impact of pH on the reaction pathway of CNNDBA, showing that within the pH range of 0–3.5, the selectivity for debenzylation was essentially 100%. However, at higher pH levels, the selectivity for debenzylation sharply decreased and was completely inhibited at pH 6. However, with the use of CNNDBA, even under acidic conditions, dechlorination occurs at a high rate as long as the pH of the reaction mixture exceeds the pKa of the protected amine (i.e. within the pH range of 4.5–7) [29]. Hwang et al.[28] studied the influence of buffers in selected solvents and adjusted the acidity and alkalinity of the mixture with acetic acid and triethylamine (TEA), respectively. They found that acidic buffers (acetic acid) promoted the conversion of NB4FA, while the reaction was significantly inhibited in the presence of alkaline buffers (TEA). However, for methanol, due to the faster reaction rates under the operating conditions, acidic buffers did not significantly enhance the conversion of NB4FA. The type and properties of the catalyst used have a crucial impact on the progress of the reaction. Typically, palladium-based catalysts are among the most commonly used due to their high activity in the hydrogenation of N-benzyl groups. While other metal catalysts may also possess the ability to catalyze the hydrogenation of N-benzyl, their activity and selectivity may not match that of palladium. Catalysts such as Pd(OH)2/C or combinations of Pd/C and acid appear to be preferred for the selective removal of N-benzyl. Optimizing the conditions for the deactivation of palladium loaded on oxides may be key to improving catalyst performance. The surface properties of the carrier influence the distribution of the catalyst in the solvent, and modified carriers may facilitate better dispersion of the catalyst in the reaction system, potentially enhancing catalytic activity. The loading amount and particle size of palladium directly affect the activity of the catalyst. When designing and optimizing catalysts, the morphology of the catalyst also needs to be considered for its impact on performance. Due to the typically weak interaction between carbon supports and active metals, the amount of palladium often needs to be increased. On the other hand, metal oxides as carriers can promote strong interactions between metal and carrier, thereby enhancing the activity and stability of the catalyst. The addition of a second metal additive may synergize with palladium, thereby promoting hydrogenation. For reactions involving different substrate structures, similar conditions apply. Polar solvents indeed enhance solubility, facilitating better contact between reactants and catalysts, thereby promoting the reaction. Similarly, under acidic conditions, organic amine compounds are more prone to protonation, aiding in the formation of more active reaction intermediates. However, it's important to note that not all reactions respond favorably to the same conditions. Acid-base conditions play a crucial role in modulating the progress of N-benzyl hydrogenation, serving as an indispensable factor in this reaction. Generally, lower pH values may promote N-benzyl removal, while higher pH values may favor alternative reaction pathways such as dehalogenation. Therefore, the reaction rate can vary depending on the acidity or alkalinity of the solution, and pH values can also influence reaction selectivity, leading to the formation of different reaction products under different pH conditions. For substrates containing both N-benzyl and O-benzyl groups, selective removal of the N-benzyl group poses challenges. However, the structure of the compound and the presence of nitrogen bases or acids can influence the selectivity of hydrogenation between O-benzyl and N-benzyl groups. This phenomenon can be utilized for selective N-debenzylation. In the selective removal of benzyl groups from molecules containing aryl halides, the choice of catalyst and solvent, as well as the addition of base or acid, have been shown to be crucial. Pd/C is the preferred catalyst. Solvents such as acetic acid or 1,2-dichlorobenzene can enhance the rate and selectivity of debenzylation reactions, possibly due to the solvent's acidity or the formation of acids during debenzylation. The N-debenzylation hydrogenation reaction of halogenated substrates is also highly sensitive to the acidity or alkalinity of the reaction system, exhibiting characteristics of promotion by acids and inhibition by bases. For the N-benzyl hydrogenation of dibenzylamine, solvent selection is crucial. Currently, reliable solvents found include trifluoroethanol, ionic liquid, and methanol mixtures, dichloromethane and methanol mixtures, among others. Additionally, the addition of a certain amount of acid enables rapid and selective debenzylation of mono- or dibenzyl derivatives. For the N-benzyl hydrogenation of some cage compounds, acetylating agents are often added to react with the amino group to protect the intermediate from ring opening. In the case of N-benzyl sulfonamides, di-tert-butyl dicarbonate can be added to activate N-benzyl sulfonamides for hydrogenation using tert-butyl carbonyl groups. For N-benzyl amide compounds, the use of neutral solvents helps prevent amide hydrogenation. In research, it is necessary to consider multiple factors comprehensively and make reasonable choices based on specific circumstances. 3.3 Stability Catalyst stability occupies a pivotal role in shaping the efficiency, cost-effectiveness, environmental impact, and overall safety of catalytic processes. In catalyst design and application, studying and optimizing the stability of catalysts is a highly important research direction. 3.3.1 The impact of different supported palladium catalysts on stability The Influence of Different Forms of Palladium on Stability Maksimowski et al.[74] reported a 42% yield after employing complex procedures to regenerate the Pd/C catalyst, which is only half of the yield achieved with a fresh catalyst. The limited recyclability of the catalyst can be attributed to its fragile stability under the reaction conditions and its susceptibility to poisoning. Due to the catalyst's low stability, Pd(OH)2/C or Pd/TiO2 catalysts, when used in HBIW hydrogenolysis, exhibited significant palladium detachment, resulting in an average palladium particle size on the recovered catalyst that was three times larger than that of the fresh catalyst. This phenomenon indicates palladium detachment and aggregation during the reaction process [4,132]. In dehalogenation and arylation reactions, some Pd elements in the Pearlman catalyst leach out and accelerate the reaction in the form of homogeneous catalysts [133]. Lou et al.[5] proposed similar observations, suggesting that dissolved palladium exhibited catalytic activity similar to that of palladium particles within the catalyst, contributing to the TADBIW debenzylation reaction. Pandarus et al.[124] introduced a sol-gel encapsulated Pd0 heterogeneous catalyst (SiliaCat-Pd(0)), composed of an organic silica matrix doped with encapsulated Pd0 nanocrystals. This catalyst demonstrated high selectivity and generality for the O- and N-debenzylation of benzyl-protecting groups under very mild conditions (room temperature, 0.1 MPa H2), even with catalyst loadings as low as 1–2 mol%. Although a substantial loss of catalyst activity was observed after three reaction runs, the activity subsequently remained relatively stable. Extending the reaction time to 1 hour and 30 minutes proved sufficient for complete debenzylation of the substrate. The Impact of Different Supports on the Stability of Supported Palladium Catalysts Zhang et al.[39] conducted a study to assess the impact of different carbon supports on the recyclability of palladium catalysts. They explored the catalytic performance of palladium catalysts loaded onto various carbon materials. Among the carbon supports they examined, disordered mesoporous carbon exhibited remarkable performance as a support in the HBIW hydrogenolysis reaction and displayed excellent cyclic stability, achieving a yield exceeding 70% after the third cycle. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) possesses high thermal stability and chemical stability towards acids and bases, making it an ideal candidate as a support for heterogeneous catalysts. Moreover, the presence of electron-rich nitrogen atoms in g-C3N4 facilitates stable and uniform deposition of metal complexes onto its surface [54]. In a separate study, Liu et al.[54] prepared a heterogeneous catalyst for debenzylation hydrogenolysis by depositing palladium particles onto mesoporous carbon nitride (mpg-C3N4) and found that the nitrogen-rich feature in C3N4 might enhance the interaction between Pd and C3N4, allowing for recycling up to three times while maintaining reasonable activity ( Fig. 4). Oxidative treatment is a convenient method for introducing oxygen functional groups onto the surface of carbon supports, which is also beneficial for improving the dispersion of active metals and enhancing the stability of catalysts [134]. Chen et al.[134] selected flower-shaped nanosheet carbon material (NSC) as the original support and modified its surface properties using nitric acid chemical oxidation and physical calcination at 600°C, denoted as NSCox-2 (treated with 20 wt% HNO3) and NSC-600, respectively. Fig. 5 provides a schematic representation of the varying oxygen functional group contents on the surfaces of flower-shaped nanosheet carbon materials treated by different methods. It was found that nitric acid chemical oxidation treatment facilitated the high dispersion of palladium on the carbon support because it introduced more oxygen-containing functional groups, thereby enhancing the interaction between palladium and the carbon support. Conversely, physical calcination had a detrimental effect on metal dispersion as it led to the decomposition of unstable carboxylic acid and anhydride groups. This indicates that in the debenzylation reaction of tetraacetyl dibenzylhexaazaisowurtzitane (TADBIW), the activity and stability of palladium catalysts are highly dependent on the oxygen functional group content on the surface of the carbon support. Specifically, the presence of a higher amount of oxygen functional groups endows the catalyst with higher activity and stability. Some researchers argue that the mesoporous structure of carbon supports enhances the anchoring effect of active sites, which helps prevent the loss and aggregation of Pd nanoparticles, thereby improving the stability of the catalyst. Furthermore, they experimentally demonstrated the importance of the interaction between active sites and substrates in maintaining catalyst stability and achieved this interaction by designing mesoporous structures through the hard template method, thus enhancing the performance of Pd/C catalysts in N-debenzylation reactions [71]. 3.3.2 The impact of solvents on the stability of supported palladium catalysts Ionic liquids, composed of organic cations and various anions, have emerged as potent solvents or catalysts owing to their unique physical and chemical attributes, including high polarity, low melting points, non-volatility, weak coordination tendencies, and immiscibility with other organic solvents [68]. There have been endeavors to employ Pd nanoparticles as catalysts within ionic liquid media [135–138]. Choi et al.[68], under mild non-acidic catalytic hydrogenolysis conditions, utilized 1-n-butyl-3-methylimidazolium (bmim) salts as co-solvents to facilitate the gentle and efficient debenzylation of various N-benzyl and N, N-dibenzylamine derivatives. In recurrent experiments, a gradual reduction in yield was observed until a sharp decline on the eighth cycle. Further research is required to elucidate the pivotal role of ionic liquids in this mild debenzylation reaction and to explore strategies for maintaining the activity of Pd in ionic liquids. 4 Applications of other metals as catalysts for N-debenzylation Nickel (Ni)-based catalysts, as low-cost alternatives to noble metal palladium catalysts, have garnered significant attention. The development of Ni molecular catalysts, i.e., Ni complexes, has been achieved through the efforts of research groups such as Sozostak [139], Takita [140], Shi [141], Zhang [142], Ritleng [143], Maiti [144], Stanley [2], Yamaguchi [1], in the field of homogeneous catalysis. In contrast, heterogeneous Ni systems offer distinct advantages, including lower cost, mechanical stability, and ease of separation from reaction media, making them of practical significance. However, only Raney Ni has been studied in specific cases[145]. Unfortunately, Raney Ni exhibits several drawbacks such as pyrophoricity, low yields, and side reactions, prompting the development of efficient and environmentally friendly heterogeneous Ni catalysts. Liu et al.[26] proposed that the hydrogenolysis of N-benzylaniline plays a crucial role in the catalytic reduction of benzaldehyde to toluene. For this purpose, they developed the catalyst suitable for this crucial step. Their approach involved the preparation of Ni30/γ-Al2O3 (30 wt% Ni) by blending pseudo-boehmite with 2% nitric acid and nickel carbonate. The reaction is conducted under conditions of 200°C and a hydrogen pressure of 2.0 MPa. Furthermore, they conducted a calcination process at 500°C to enhance the catalyst's catalytic hydrogenolysis capabilities. Notably, the catalyst demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance, with Ni0 being identified as the active site for both hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis. Using N-benzylaniline as the reactant, Pd catalysts only require mild experimental conditions (1 mol% Pd, 35°C, H2 1 atm), whereas this catalyst necessitates relatively high reaction temperatures and catalyst loading. This constitutes a rare example of non-precious metal catalysis for direct C-N bond hydrogenolysis, providing insights for future advancements in this field. It has been reported that the Ni−N−C@Al2O3-1000 catalyst is highly efficient for O-debenzylation and N-debenzylation of various substrates using H2 as the reducing agent [146]. However, in this report, only one substrate containing an N-benzyl group (8 mol% Ni，140℃, H2 30 bar), namely N-benzylaniline, was mentioned, and its debenzylation yield was relatively low (72%). Liu et al.[25] designed a highly efficient heterogeneous nickel catalyst for C-N bond cleavage and debenzylation. They utilized a Ni−Al layered double hydroxide precursor and in-situ generated Ni nanoparticles through pure H2 reduction ( Fig. 6). The reactions for each substrate are conducted under conditions of 120–150°C and hydrogen pressure ranging from 20 to 70 bar. The resulting Ni NPs exhibited complete hydrogenolysis and debenzylation of aniline compounds, with yields exceeding 90%. In the clay structure, Ni2+ and Al3+ metal ions appear as basic M2+ and M3+ cations; the charge-compensating anion of An- is the hydroxide ion OH-. This layered structure served as a confined space, effectively inhibiting nickel growth. Consequently, they prepared a supported nickel catalyst using Ni–Al hydrotalcite-like compounds as a foundation.
