Moreover, this structure enhanced the interaction between metal nickel and the support, suppressing catalyst aggregation and sintering, maintaining catalyst stability, and ultimately improving unexpected catalytic performance [147,148]. In the synthesis of salbutamol, Leitch et al.[7] were the first to report the use of ruthenium-based catalysts for the selective N-Benzyl hydrogenolysis ( Scheme 21). They discovered that 5% Ru/Al2O3 serves as a highly efficient substitute for Pd/C. While this ruthenium catalyst may necessitate a slightly higher H2 pressure (no reaction was observed at 1 atm), it offers a cost advantage over Pd. However, currently, we lack further understanding of the application of ruthenium-based catalysts in N-benzyl hydrogenation reactions, indicating that there is still a long way to go for the application of ruthenium-based catalysts. Attempts to directly convert indolizidines into monobenzylated secondary amines using supported palladium catalysis have been found to be successful. Unfortunately, the enantioselectivity of these reactions is too low. In a study conducted by Albaladejo et al.[27], which explored the potential for selective hydrogenolysis using the two benzyl groups present in imidazolidine enantiomers ( Scheme 22), PtO2 or Pt(5 wt%)/C catalysts were employed to facilitate the monobenzylation process and generate secondary amine 2. Both PtO2 and Pt/C(5 wt%) catalysts can selectively catalyze monodebenzylation reactions at room temperature and atmospheric hydrogen pressure, yielding the monobenzylated counterparts 2 in moderate to high yields. It's noteworthy that acidic solvents have the propensity to corrode the catalyst, consequently impeding cyclic catalytic performance. Although N-benzyl hydrogenation reactions have attracted considerable attention in the field of catalysis, research on the application of non-metal catalysts in this reaction is still relatively rare. There are many unknown areas to explore in both theoretical and experimental aspects regarding the application of non-metal catalysts. For example, our understanding of the catalytic mechanism and active sites of non-metal catalysts in N-benzyl hydrogenation reactions is still not sufficiently deep, requiring further research to reveal the underlying reaction processes. Additionally, it is necessary to optimize and improve the synthesis methods, structural characteristics, and catalytic performance of non-metal catalysts to enhance their efficiency and selectivity in N-benzyl hydrogenation reactions. Therefore, although non-metal catalysts hold great potential for N-benzyl hydrogenation reactions, there are still many challenges and opportunities that need to be addressed through further research and efforts to realize their widespread application in this field. 5 Conclusion In this literature review, we explore the research on the catalytic hydrogenolysis of N-benzyl compounds and their corresponding catalysts. Our comprehensive analysis of multiple studies provides insights into the catalytic mechanisms and kinetic characteristics of this reaction. We particularly focus on an in-depth examination of supported palladium catalysts, scrutinizing their activity, selectivity, and stability within the reaction. These findings offer valuable insights for both catalyst design and the optimization of reaction conditions. Many scholars have confirmed the high efficiency of Pd(OH)2 catalyst in N-benzyl hydrogenation reactions. Optimizing the passivation conditions of palladium loaded on oxides may be crucial for improving their performance. The properties of the carrier influence the dispersion of the catalyst in the reaction system, and modified carriers may enhance catalytic activity. The loading amount and particle size of Pd directly affect the catalytic activity, and morphology also needs to be considered. The interaction between carbon carriers and active metals is weak, so it often requires an increase in Pd dosage; while metal oxide carriers can promote strong interactions, enhancing the activity and stability of the catalyst. The addition of a second metal additive may synergize with palladium, promoting hydrogenation. The importance of acid-base conditions in N-benzyl hydrogenation reactions is notable. Polar solvents facilitate increased solubility, promoting reaction progress; under acidic conditions, organic amine compounds are more prone to protonation, forming more active reaction intermediates. However, not all reactions are suitable under the same conditions. Acid-base conditions can influence reaction rates and selectivity, with lower pH values possibly facilitating N-benzyl removal, while higher pH values may be more favorable for other reaction pathways. Therefore, acidity and basicity are crucial for the progress of N-benzyl hydrogenation reactions. Additionally, we briefly introduce the application of alternative metal catalysts in this reaction, which can inspire future research directions. These research findings indicate that supported palladium catalysts exhibit high catalytic activity and good selectivity in catalyzing the N-benzyl hydrogenolysis reaction, but their stability still faces challenges. To further enhance the preparation of Pd catalysts, we can refine methods to control their structure, morphology, and crystal phase, aiming to improve both catalytic activity and stability. This could involve exploring novel carrier materials, synthesis strategies, and passivation techniques to achieve more precise catalyst design. Additionally, delving into the properties of carrier materials and their influence on catalyst performance—such as surface structure, pore distribution, and acidity/basicity—will be crucial. Investigating how adjustments to these properties can optimize catalyst dispersion and active site density will be key to enhancing catalytic performance. Furthermore, it is necessary to systematically study the mechanism and kinetics of N-benzyl hydrogenation under various reaction conditions, especially acidity/alkalinity and solvent selection, as well as their influence on reaction pathways and product selectivity. Determining the optimal reaction conditions is crucial for achieving efficient and selective reaction conversions. In addition to Pd catalysts, exploring the application of other metal catalysts or multi-metal catalytic systems in N-benzyl hydrogenolysis reactions could yield promising alternatives. Comparative studies on the performance and stability of different catalytic systems will help identify alternatives with enhanced activity and selectivity. Moreover, a deeper investigation into the catalytic mechanisms and formation and conversion processes of reaction intermediates in N-benzyl hydrogenolysis is necessary. Utilizing advanced characterization techniques and computational simulation methods to unveil the interactions between catalysts and substrates will provide valuable theoretical guidance for further optimizing catalytic systems. In conclusion, this literature review furnishes indispensable reference material for the study of catalytic N-benzyl hydrogenolysis reactions. By conducting an extensive analysis of existing research, we achieve a profound comprehension of the relevant characteristics and mechanisms governing this reaction. These insights provide valuable guidance for the improvement of catalyst performance, the augmentation of reaction efficiency, and the innovation of novel catalysts. This review carries substantial potential for advancing research in this field and propelling progress in associated scientific domains. coredata.dc:description: The current review offers a comprehensive analysis of the catalytic N-benzyl hydrogenolysis debenzylation reaction, encompassing an examination of the catalytic mechanism and kinetic characteristics. Among the various catalysts employed in C−N hydrolysis, the supported palladium catalyst stands out as the most frequently employed catalyst. This review thoroughly elucidates the utilization of palladium catalyst in N-benzyl catalytic hydrogenolysis, providing insights into its activity, selectivity, and stability concerning support materials, cocatalysts, solvents, and pH conditions. These findings yield valuable insights for optimizing catalyst design and reaction conditions. Additionally, we briefly introduce the applications of other metallic catalysts such as nickel and platinum in catalyzing N-benzyl hydrogenolysis reactions. This provides valuable guidance for advancing our understanding of the hydrogenolysis reaction mechanisms, enhancing catalyst performance, and developing novel catalytic agents.
